App description:
Venture into the wildest places on earth and meet the humans protecting our most precious wildlife. Explore the great savannahs of Kenya, discover the ancient jungles of Borneo and dive into the rich coral reefs of Raja Ampat. Encounter elephants, orangutans, manta rays and some incredible humans, all in stunning cinematic footage filmed from the air and deep into the ocean.

ecosphere sets out to redefine the limits of 3D-180 cameras, natural history storytelling and conservation filmmaking. Travel to natures most fragile and diverse ecosystems, where indigenous and community-led efforts are creating space for humanity and wildlife to thrive together.

ecosphere is an uplifting nature documentary series by the award winning studio PHORIA. Produced in partnership with World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), Silverback Films Ltd and Oculus, this groundbreaking series is narrated by Emmy Award winning actress Anna Friel.

Palaxax22 days ago
Pretty Good

I liked the documentaries and I think this might be the way forward for TV in the future once the technology improves and is more accessible to everyday people. The Quest goes a long way, but I think it's going to take another decade before everyone has one of these in their homes.

The scenery is beautiful, but I was a bit disappointed that there were only 3 documentaries. Still, it's a fascinating experience to watch a documentary in VR and I'd recommend the experience to everybody. I was surprised on several occasions when an animal "got close" to me, but that's part of why it was fun. It scared the crap out of me when the orangutan landed right in front of me, but in a good way!

TorisHusbandJun 27 at 3:39 PM
How is this free?

Im probably the only person here that found this from the camera manufacturers website under samples. Its filmed on the Brand new, unreleased ZCam K2 Pro and while I can understand the need for compression, would personally love to pay to have the full resolution files. To any Quest users reading this, disregard all the negative comments if their main qualm is about it not being in 360; 180 has a higher potential for quality as it allows sets to use & hide lights, diffusers, and immersive mic setups - not to mention resolution in regards to processing power on the Quest. Anyone up in arms about the 180 element is simply ignorant of the technical feats that are going on right behind the camera. These are 10+ minute 6K 60p films that they compressed really well, especially considering under 2gb a piece. People clearly take the complexity of their eyes for granted as they falsely undermine and compare it to technology.

Thank you for doing this, planning on financially supporting this venture! One of my VR videos: https://youtu.be/nZrN6mcJqks

Helpful | 4

nr6542Jun 17 at 1:14 PM
NOTE: You should stand! (Probably)

At least with the video on Africa, the camera was set up from a standing point of view. If you watch it seated, the elephants will seem small. If you stand however, they seem as big as they should. Give it a shot!

Unfortunately, while the idea of this is great, the execution is poor. For example, the camera height varies throughout a video. So whether you stand or sit, you're always either not far enough off the ground or too far off it compared to how it was recorded. You'd think that companies that spend so much money on creating content like this would experiment with such absolutely basic things before shooting tons of material.

Another problem is that the image position isn't fixed. Which means that as you move your head, the image slightly moves with it. For one thing, that made me feel slightly disoriented, for another, it breaks immersion.

Compression also seems worse than what it could be. It's only about 18 MBit/sec. and I'm pretty sure that I've seen 180 deg. 3D videos of better quality. There should also be streaming options because while the Quest doesn't have a lot of storage space, there are many people who have >50 MBit connections (which means that they could easily compress less AND offer streaming).

Weird how long VR has been around for now and what budget we're probably looking at here and yet, they didn't get so many pretty simple/basic things right.
Guess it'll be another few years before we'll see decent 180/360 3D video content. (What I've seen on Youtube has been pretty bad as well. Pretty much the only somewhat decent one I've found so far is "ASMR / Meditation - Welsh Coastline" on Vuze. That's it.)
